Award.AwardTitle: SHB: Type II (INT): Collaborative Research: Creating Learning Systems with Mobile Technology to Improve Coordination in Perioperative Services

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project proposes to create a framework using a combination of mobile technology, learning systems, data analytics, education, and training to enhance cooperation and coordination of staff within and across perioperative services departments (POS). Perioperative services comprise surgery preparation, operating rooms, post-anesthesia care, sterile processing and a variety of other services, such as radiology and endoscopy. The specific objectives of this project are to: (1) enhance communication and coordination among POS staff to improve the quality of care by gathering and using important workflow milestones and introducing artificial intelligence techniques through the use of a smart-app, (2) analyze workflow data gathered with smart-apps using data analytics to provide intuitive displays of real-time information for frontline staff and a daily performance dashboard for managers, and (3) induce behavioral and cultural change in healthcare systems through training and education. While existing information technology capabilities such as natural language processing, artificial intelligence, and speech recognition technology are promising developments in computing, their uses in health care are limited and thus need to be thoroughly investigated before they can be used in health care effectively. To accomplish these objectives, the research team will work closely with the partnering healthcare organizations, Greenville Hospital System (GHS), Palmetto Health (Palmetto), and the Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC), in developing the tools and models which will be pilot-tested at these organizations by their staff.

The developed tools and models will be widely disseminated among health care providers in South Carolina. In addition, the smart-apps and agent-based simulation model will provide the team with a teaching and training tool that can be used in the classroom at Clemson University and the University of South Carolina (USC) to teach students across a variety of fields, such as business, engineering, science and healthcare students about information and workflow management techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal was to create new tools for healthcare providers to achieve improved coordination among Perioperative Services departments within hospitals by:

  1. 1.      Improving individual workflows via synchronization of activities
  2. 2.      Identifying and resolving systemic issues via mobile communication tools and presenting data intuitively
  3. 3.      Inducing behavioral and cultural change in healthcare systems through technology, training and education

To address the goal, the project team completed the following tasks:

  • Gathering, documenting, and organizing Periop process workflow information within preoperative, operating room, and postoperative units at participating facility locations
  • Developing various components of the smart-app, including basic artificial intelligence (e.g., voice recognition), role-specific interface screens, and department-level status information
  • Preparing a day-of-surgery simulation model to interact in a mobile environment for use as an educational tool for staff
  • Developing an interactive simulation platform for user testing the mobile app at multiple facilities. A discrete-event simulation model was combined with a web service platform to connect to the mobile app to test day-of-surgery scenarios and evaluate the functionality of the app
  • Completing the user testing of the app with selected staff roles and recording staff feedback on the ability of the smart app to address shortcomings in the communication and coordination processes currently in place. A final research paper is now being prepared.

Each faculty and student investigator was provided the opportunity to spend time in the hospital environment, engage in interviews with staff in Periop, and participate in observations of staff responsibilities. Hospital staff had the opportunity to see how the research team envisioned a smart-app would work in their setting, and they were able to provide meaningful feedback on the important features to consider in such an app. Staff were then exposed to the tool using a simulated training environment. Education about the use of such a mobile app can extend beyond the staff within the hospital where Periop MLS may be deployed.

Healthcare professionals across the state of South Carolina can have access to the simulation training upon request through the Periop MLS website. The training combines the mobile app and day-of-surgery simulation to demonstrate to healthcare professionals how such information about patient flow/status can be used more effectively. Development of the prototype tool and user testing was completed in 2017-2018.
